column3:
There are not many places that offer real barbacoa meat in Mexico City.  But this place is a MUST try.

We came here on the other day and The food was super delicious and big portion.  The service was exceptional. The owner was extremely welcoming and super nice.  They offer a different variety of items options on their menu.  You can order individual item or set menu .   Prices are very reasonable.

They slowly cook their barbacoa meat in a huge fire pit covered with some kind of leaves and sand.  They cooked their meat for at least few hours.

We ordered their set menu for 2 people.  It was a lot of food.  It came with consomÃ© ( soup )

column3: Muy buena atenciÃ³n por parte de sus empleados.

It's rare for me to write a 2 star review but despite all our excitement our lunch at Quintonil was a big disappointment at our recent visit.

There is no doubting the talent of the chef and kitchen and overall we have no major quibbles with the quality of the food itself - though it was something in line with something we might expect in a 1 michelin star establishment rather than purportedly one of the worlds finest restaurants.  Everything looked and tasted just fine but there werent any moments of true joy or inspiration for us.

The real disappointment was in the ambience and character of the restaurant.  The lighting was beyond terrible.  The furinishings lacklustre.  The tables were placed far too close so we could hear all the conversations close to us making it difficult to really enjoy the meal or each others company.  Unbelievably
column4:
the table decor was composed of fake plastic lemons.   The cocktails we ordered were so bad they made us laugh.  The chocolates we werent ablet to finish at the end of our meal were presented to us in a shabby styroform take out box you might find a roadside cafe.

We have no qualms on spending decent money on terrific food but by the time our bill arrived we felt thoroughly cheated.

In hindsight
column5: we wished we'd left midway through the meal.  What was meant to be one of the highlights of our trip to mexico felt more like an ordeal and we both breathed a mutual sigh of relief as we left the dark

column3: The food here is no better than other restaurants we have eaten at in Mexico City at half the price.  Compared to tasting menus we have had at top restaurants in New York where you also have to book a month in advance the portions were tiny.  Someone in our party ordered ala carts and her entree was a bowl of mole sauce with a few mushrooms scattered on the side and ONE piece of bread (see photo).  Would it have been so hard to give her multiple pieces to use with the sauce.  When asked for a second piece of bread we got attitude.  Theservice was really terrible - we waited 10-20 minutes between finishing one course and getting the. next.  It was so bad I started timing the intervals.  At various points they came and put down plates and then removed them without serving us anything.  Our waiter would approach our table and see us sitting and waiting... a guilty look would pass over his face and then he would turn around and say nothing.  The tables around us also seemed to be waiting and bored.  If the kitchen was having issues they should have at least offered us free water or a drink or something.  The tiny entree that was all sauce was really a total rip off

column3:
Food was fantastic and great service expect the waiter waiting on us was trying to rip us off
In Mexico generally you donâ€™t have to tip but if the service is good you can tip 10%-15%(if itâ€™s really good). So when the bill came and the waiter asked me how much I would like to tip I said 10%. Instead of choosing 10% on the machine in front of my eyes he turned his back towards me and then handed me the check to sign.
I thought that was weird and noticed the tip was at 20% on my bill. So I told him I donâ€™t care about the extra few dollars but it was very dishonest what he was doing and ruined my experience of the night because the food was really good. He turned red immediately and pretended he doesnâ€™t understand me anymore (even though he was speaking English to me all through dinner).

Itâ€™s a very authentic place so I would still recommend anyone to try this place but if you are a tourist like me watch out on the final bill lol
Truly authentic Mexican food n excellent service.

column3:
Tourists beware - this place will try to rip you off. We started off pleasantly and enjoyed our medicore food (and good wine pours) only to be foiled by an attempted scam at the end of our meal.

The waitress who brought the bill was not one who had attended to us
column4: and gave us a hand written tab. She then immediately told us their card reader wasn't working and we would have to pay in cash. When we looked at the "bill"
column5: we saw they had charged us more for every single item that was listed. Water bottles on the menu were listed at 25 pesos
column6: and we had 3 but they wrote down $150 MX. Our pizzas were $110 on the menu
column7: but they had listed them as $120. Our wine they charged $210 pesos and we couldn't dispute that unfortunately because they did not list the wine on the menu
column8: but they did charge us for 4 instead of 3. When we told them we only had a card
column9: they told is they could do a partial card charge and a partial cash charge which still makes zero sense to me
column10: but by that time we were so frustrated that we just wanted to leave. We got them to agree to their posted menu prices
column11: and our waiter claimed the upcharge was for his tip. Well
column12: no tip for you! What a shame
column13: this place could be great
column14: even with the garbage food.

Landed a few hours ago and came here because it was a short walk from the hotel.  Google ratings did not disappoint.
I started with the water of the day which was a pineapple guava ginger infusion.  The bread and peanut garlic and pepper dipping sauce was so darn flavorful.
My â€œstarterâ€ was the roasted bone marrow and I only had one complaint; I finished it too quickly.  Itâ€™s two big bones with the marrow so succulent.  The marrow is then topped with a delightful tomatillo sauce.  It was served with blue tostada and pico which were both well above average.
The closer was the octopus.  First off

column3:
Exquisite tasting menu that will leave you feeling full & wholesome ðŸ’œ

The restaurant setting is beautiful - thereâ€™s a Japanese zen garden vibe to it. The recurring motif of circles is prevalent both in the decor & food presentation.

Snacks: well balanced layers of flavors. The sauce for the corn is finger-licking good (please sell them in jars ðŸ˜‹)

Chayote: beautiful dish inside out - but relatively less memorable flavors

Ceviche: one of our favorite dishes. The mouthwatering citrus flavor will make you drink every last bit of the sauce.

Papadzul: wish there are more Korean-Mexican fusion food out there. The juiciness of the mushrooms matches phenomenally with the kimchi.

Striped bass: Japanese-influenced dish & another highlight of the meal! Everything on the plate is executed on point: from the tenderness of the sea bass
column4: to the thoughtful sauce for the vegetables
column5:
and the sushi rice ball covered with seaweed powder. I can eat a bento box of this.

Mole: one of their signature dishes
column6:
& unfortunately the only dish we did not care for. Guess weâ€™re just not into mole?

Palette cleanser (sorbet)
column7: yogurt ice cream
column8: churro/fig: the palette cleanser & yogurt ice cream are too similar/repetitive IMO. Nevertheless
column9: the yogurt ice cream is very tasty & rich in honey flavor
column10:
and reminds me of ice cream with shaved ice (common dessert in Asia). The meal wraps up perfectly with churro (hope they can make a gluten-free version in the future).

Wine pairing: excellent selection offered & reasonable pouring. I think it can be even more unique/special to feature local wines.

Seating: during COVID times
column11:
I think the seating could be further spaced out to create a better sense of social distancing.

Service: attentive & good as you would expect at a high-end establishment.

Question: are the staff saying â€œadiosâ€ to the food before they were brought out from the kitchen? ðŸ˜ We could not decipher what they were saying in unison.

column3: First and foremost the food was decent but not spectacular. The first few courses were better than the rest
column4:
but I have no complaints about it. The inside of the restaurant is also beautiful and stunning.

However
column5: the experience was horrendous because of the lack of care that the restaurant had with regards to safety. I have never been in a restaurant during COVID
column6: in both the US and Mexico
column7: that packs so many people in such a small area
column8: all within touching distance from one another. While all the employees had both masks and face shields
column9:
the clients are packed almost shoulder to shoulder. I have no doubt that if one person had COVID all of us would be infected. Typically I am not too worried about the virus but Pujol was so ridiculous with this that it absolutely destroyed the experience.

I made a comment to both the waiter and the manager
column10: and after a back and forth discussion during which they told us that they werenâ€™t open seats because it was a full house
column11:
they finally moved us. They also gave us a few extra dishes and a quarter portion of free wine which was nice. They ended up charging us the full amount which was fine. That wasnâ€™t the point. We didnâ€™t sign up to pay $150+ just to complain and get an extra dish - we were there to enjoy the experience.

If the owner of the restaurant is reading this
column12:
you should feel ashamed of yourself and for putting your customers at risk. It really is unethical for such a highly regarded and expensive restaurant. Build more barriers and space out the seats. Of all restaurants in the world you can probably afford to take a slight hit for the safety of others.

If you are a potential client
column13: I would be aware of this especially if you are in a high risk group and at the minimum ask for a seat outside or in the corner near the entrance / exit.

column3: The food and presentation where above average and I especially loved how fair the prices were for the quality and location in one of the most expensive neighborhoods of Mexico. I never know with these kinds of caliber of restaurants what actually has a cost or what is part of the service/ an amuse bouche. they do give you free (tiny) portions of traditional mexican sweets at the end with the check which is a nice touch.
